Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

International Paper is fully committed to operating and maintaining each of its business sites in compliance with all applicable safety and environmental laws, regulations and permits.  We are committed to removing the conditions and behaviors that cause personal injury or environmental impact.  International Paper Environment, Health and Safety Policy (EHS#10000) states "An essential part of our business strategy is to make products in a safe and healthful work place, to manage natural resources wisely, and to continually improve our environmental performance.  We are committed to removing the conditions and behaviors that cause personal injury or environmental impact."  Corporate policy (EHS#10101) states the business site manager responsibilities for complying with International Paper's Environment, Health and Safety Policy and Principles and environment, health and safety (EHS) regulations. It establishes the requirements for 100% compliance, self-audit programs, compliance certifications and corporate reporting.  The Riverdale Mill strictly adheres to these policies.  

As an example of our commitment to safety, the Riverdale Mill maintains the highly coveted Star status in OSHA's Voluntary Protection Program (VPP).  The VPP program promotes effective programs for worksite-based safety and health.  In VPP, management, labor and OSHA establish cooperative relationships at workplaces that have implemented a comprehensive safety and health management system.  Approval into VPP is OSHA's official recognition of the outstanding efforts of employers and employees who have achieved exemplary occupational safety and health.

International Paper is committed to providing all personnel at the mill site and the surrounding community with a safe environment.  Creating an environment that fulfills this commitment is given our highest priority.  Our emergency response plan is written and designed to assist

Riverdale Mill management, employees and responding outside agencies through emergency response actions as a part of this commitment.  Comprehensive safety rules exist for all employees, contractors and visitors.  The Riverdale Mill Safety Rules state that all employees must comply with all safety policies/practices established by the company.  Any violations can result in disciplinary action up to and including discharge.  The Riverdale Mill Safety Standards published by the Riverdale Mill manager cover the following:  Safety Principles, Safety Expectations, Role of Safety Leaders and Safety as a Value.  A common message in our various safety publications is our commitment that International Paper will never put production above the safety of people, that no employee, contractor or visitor will get hurt, and that everyone will learn and follow safety procedures.

The Riverdale Mill and the Regulated Substances Handled

International Paper owns and operates the Riverdale Mill, an integrated pulp and paper mill, located in central Alabama about 10 miles east of Selma.  The original mill was built in the mid-60's by Hammermill Paper Company.  International Paper acquired the facility in 1986.  Having undergone several major expansions over the years, the Riverdale Mill developed into a world class leader in the manufacture of pulp and paper.  Today, the mill produces virgin and recycled grades of white reprographic paper (copy paper) and offset paper rolls.  The Riverdale Mill employs about 750 people, making it Dallas County's largest employer.   

The paper making process begins with a woodyard where about 5,000 tons of tree length wood is received each day.  These trees are chipped by species (hardwood and softwood).  The chips are then cooked in a series of digesters which turn the wood chips into brown pulp.  The brown pulp undergoes some additional refining, then bleached to turn the pulp white.  The bleaching process requires the use of chlorine dioxide w

hich is a substance regulated under the RMP rule.  The bleached pulp is then converted to large rolls of paper on two large paper machines.  A sheeting operation cuts the large rolls of paper into copier size sheets which are packaged into reams, boxed, palletized and sent to the warehouse for shipment by truck and rail to destinations throughout the U.S.  Supporting operations at Riverdale include a deinking plant that converts recycled paper into clean, recycled fiber used in making recycled grades of paper, a power plant operation that generates electricity and steam which derives 75 percent of its energy needs from renewable fuels (black liquor and waste wood fuel), and other chemical recovery operations.

As previously stated, a bleaching process is required to convert brown pulp into a white or bleached pulp in order to make a paper acceptable to the consumer.  At Riverdale, this is accomplished through the use of chlorine dioxide.  As part of our commitment to environmental stewardship, in the 1990's, International Paper converted the pulp bleaching process from elemental chlorine (i.e., chlorine gas, or Cl2) to the more environmentally friendly elemental chlorine free (ECF) bleach using chlorine dioxide (ClO2).  The Riverdale mill has two chlorine dioxide generators that create chlorine dioxide solution at 9.5 grams per liter (g/L) to 10.5 (g/L).  The U.S. EPA Risk Management Program regulates ClO2 when it is stored in solutions above 10 g/L (i.e. one weight percent) with a total mass of ClO2 greater that 1,000 pounds.  Even though the ClO2 generated is often below 10g/l, International Paper took a conservative approach and entered the program in good faith to ensure compliance and protection of public health and the environment.  The generated ClO2 is stored in three tanks prior to use in the bleaching process.  Because the Riverdale mill is a pulp and paper mill and the worst-case modeling predicts the potential for off-site impacts, Program 3 of the RMP

is applicable.  Program 3 requires both worst-case modeling analysis and an alternative analysis.  Both analyses are included in our plan.

General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

This facility is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) rule for highly hazardous chemicals designed to prevent unwanted releases of these chemicals.  An effective process safety management program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the entire chemical process.  At Riverdale, a comprehensive PSM program was developed to ensure compliance.  The Riverdale program covers 14 elements that include employee involvement, process safety information, process hazard analysis, management of change, pre-startup safety review, operating procedures, incident investigation, mechanical integrity, hot work, emergency planning and response, contractors, training, compliance audits and trade secrets.  The entire PSM program is audited every three years.  All operators and maintenance personnel in PSM process areas receive initial training on these elements and refresher training at least every three years.  A PSM coordinator is assigned the task of managing the overall program. 

Five Year Accident History

This facility has not experienced any releases during the last 5 years that are reportable under RMP.  

The Emergency Response Program

A comprehensive emergency response and evacuation plan is maintained by the Riverdale mill.  The emergency response plan was developed to provide direction to mill personnel in managing an emergency condition to ensure the health and safety of all personnel and the surrounding communities, protect the environment and minimize damage to property.  The plan establishes the definition of an emergency, assessment, alarms, responsibilities, evacuation routes and procedures, notification of mill and off-site personnel and organizations, timely and effective mitigation of the emergency, management o

f emergency response activities and recovery from the emergency condition.
The Riverdale fire brigade/hazmat team consists of approximately 50 members that are all volunteers from the mill work force.  Team members are spread over four shifts so there are always qualified hazmat personnel on-site.   These employees receive comprehensive off-site hazmat operational and technician level training annually.  Select personnel receive on-scene incident commander training.  A full scale hazmat drill is also conducted at this training.  Periodic training is conducted for the team at the mill which includes equipment familiarization.  The mill equipment includes a hazmat response vehicle equipped with an incident command center, air compressor for filling breathing air bottles, fire hoses, nozzles, foam educators, fire fighting gear, level A and B hazmat suits, SCBA's, rescue equipment, equipment designed to repair/plug leaks, medical supplies, etc.

All mill employees receive annual evacuation training that includes a written test.  Additionally, evacuation drills are conducted annually.  Training is also included in the contractor training program and contractors present during our annual drills are required to participate.  Off-site evacuation is coordinated through the LEPC.
Local fire departments are periodically invited to the mill in order to review our hazards and facility layout.  The city of Selma provides both hazmat and fire fighting support if needed.    

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Changes are currently being evaluated to improve safety as a result of recommendations from the recent Process Hazard Analysis and 3-year Compliance Audit.
